awd_titl_txt: CICI: UCSS: Helix++: Securing Open Science Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
The Helix++ project’s goal is to use recently developed, promising cybersecurity research results to secure open-science platforms. Securing these open-science platforms is vital because compromise of research infrastructure can have severe consequences, including the delay of critical research, corruption of research results, theft of intellectual property, and exposure of personally identifiable information. Beyond providing researchers customized, secure packages of widely used open software, the Helix++ project will provide insights and directions for future research and strategies for protecting critical cyber infrastructure. Using two existing operational open-science platforms at the University of Virginia, the project will investigate the interaction of technical and policy issues which are fundamental to infrastructure protection.

The open-source Helix++ project improves the security posture of open science platforms by applying cutting-edge cybersecurity techniques to diversify and harden software automatically. A distinguishing feature of Helix++ is that it does not require source code or build artifacts. It operates directly on software in binary form—even stripped executables and libraries. This feature is key as rebuilding applications from source is a time-consuming and often frustrating process. Helix++ enables the rapid generation and deployment of secure containers and virtual machines, wherein various applications and libraries are transformed to incorporate the Helix++ protections. Diversification breaks the software monoculture and makes attacks harder to execute as information needed for a successful attack will have changed unpredictably. Diversification also forces attackers to customize an attack for each target instead of attackers crafting an exploit that works reliably on all similarly configured targets. Hardening directly targets key attack classes. The combination of diversity and hardening provides defense-in-depth, as well as a moving target defense. Helix++ is evaluated on two open science platforms to demonstrate its efficacy and usability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Helix++ project aimed to enhance the security of open science research cyberinfrastructures by developing and applying innovative cybersecurity methods to diversify and strengthen software defenses. This initiative primarily focused on packaging and distributing these methods to the cybersecurity community, enabling them to secure complex scientific software systems.

Intellectual Merit
The Helix++ project introduced significant advancements in the field of cybersecurity, mainly through two core technologies: Zipr and ZAFL. These tools enable automated software hardening and fuzz testing, which help detect vulnerabilities and mitigate zero-day exploits. As a result of this research, Zipr technology was featured as a finalist in the inaugural Cybersecurity Artifacts and Impact award competition at the 2023 Annual Computer Security Application Conference (ACSAC). This recognition highlighted Zipr's impact on security research and its potential for practical application.

Other significant project outcomes were collaborations with the Department of Defense's Test Resource Management Center (TRMC) and the University of Utah. Through the partnership with TRMC, a proposal to integrate ZAFL into TRMC's Vader Modular Fuzzer (VMF) was submitted. The Department of Defense uses VMF to test software systems for vulnerabilities. TRMC selected the project for funding, enabling the integration of ZAFL and related technology into VMF. This integration will facilitate enhanced code coverage, crash triage, and automated harnessing, setting a precedent for robust, scalable security solutions in government and research infrastructures.

The collaboration with the University of Utah focused on transitioning research in cybersecurity, software engineering, and systems to develop techniques to enable thorough, systematic vetting of scientific software.  This collaborative project will enable the application of high-performance, systematic fuzzing techniques to today's scientific software ecosystem, thereby combating the ever-increasing threat of cyber attacks that target scientific cyberinfrastructure.

Broader Impacts
Beyond advancing knowledge in cybersecurity, Helix++ has contributed to educational and training initiatives. The project involved graduate and undergraduate students in advanced cybersecurity research, providing them with hands-on experience in cutting-edge technologies. Furthermore, course material derived from the project was integrated into a cybersecurity capstone course at the University of Virginia, where students learn to apply complex security techniques, including fuzz testing and automated software diversification.

The project's outcomes have also had substantial practical implications. The automated hardening of Docker containers, one of the project's key technical achievements, makes it possible to deploy secure software images easily and quickly. This hardened container capability enables scientific computing environments at leading institutions to safeguard research data and applications from potential cyber threats.

Conclusion
The Helix++ project has successfully advanced both cybersecurity technology and the education of future cybersecurity professionals. By fostering collaborations, securing ongoing funding for future integrations, and creating tools that improve security for complex software systems, Helix++ has laid a foundation for more secure scientific research infrastructures. These achievements promise to benefit not only the cybersecurity community, but also the broader scientific community, enhancing both the safety and integrity of digital research environments.
